node.text: La ecografía abre una nueva ventana en el diagnóstico y seguimiento de los pacientes con patologías reumatológicas, el Dr. Javier Merayo (@javier_merayo), miembro del Comité editorial de Medscape en español, y el Dr. Mario Chávez López (@drmariochavez) comentan el alcance, las aplicaciones, el uso y el impacto en la clínica.

node.title: Ecografía musculoesquelética en la práctica clínica del reumatólogo

node.text: El Dr. Javier Merayo (@javier_merayo), miembro del Comité editorial de Medscape en español, y el Dr. Fabricio Espinosa Ortega comentan aspectos relevantes sobre la frecuencia, el diagnóstico, valor de los anticuerpos y manejo de las miopatías inflamatorias o miositis. ¿Conocen cuáles son las más frecuentes en su región?

node.text:
A conversation with Abraham Verghese MD, Eric Topol MD, and Danielle Ofri MD about the role of writing during the Covid pandemic. Join the premiere on Tuesday March 23 at 7 pm EST 
@blreview YouTube Page
tinyURL / BLRViral

Readings from today:
"A Doctor's Pandemic Diary" by Danielle Ofri MD (from the New Yorker)
Evocation (Streets) by Jeanette Clough (from BLR)

@blreview @danielle_ofri

node.text:
Medical Monday Case Challenge: NSCLC + Antiangiogenics⁠
⁠
In patients with NSCLC, antiangiogenic therapy shows modest benefit. ⁠
⁠
However, patients with nonsquamous histology, absence of ___, and no hemoptysis may be candidates for treatment. ⁠
⁠
What’s the missing qualifier?⁠
⁠
A. Liver metastases⁠
⁠
B. K -ras mutations⁠
⁠
C. Cranial metastases⁠
⁠
D. PD-L1 expression⁠
⁠
⁠
The correct response to this question will be listed in the comments tomorrow.

node.text:
Lyme Disease May Up Mental Illness Risks⁠
⁠
Patients with Lyme disease are at increased risk for any mental disorder, for affective disorders, and for suicidal behavior, new research suggests.⁠
⁠
Results from a large population-based study show that the rate of depression was 42% higher among patients with Lyme disease than among persons who did not have a history of Lyme disease; the rate of suicide was 75% higher, said lead author Brian A. Fallon, MD, professor of clinical psychiatry and director of the Lyme and Tick-Borne Diseases Research Center, Columbia University, New York City.⁠
⁠
Lyme disease, which is caused by bacteria carried by infected ticks, can lead to severe pain syndromes, debilitating fatigue, and neurologic problems. ⁠
⁠
The prevalence of Lyme disease appears to be increasing in the United States as ticks spread beyond the epicenters of the Northeast and Midwest, said Fallon.⁠
⁠
Results from the fully adjusted model show that the rate of any mental disorder was 28% higher among participants with Lyme borreliosis compared with those without the disorder.⁠
⁠
In addition, the rate of suicide attempts was about double for the group with Lyme disease .⁠
⁠
For those of you who treat #Lyme, are you seeing this in your practice?⁠
⁠
Full report + references available with a tap to the link in bio.

node.text:
Medscape Clinical Trend: IBD⁠⁠
⁠⁠
New research found an association between consumption of overprocessed foods and an increased risk for IBD. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Ultraprocessed food was defined as all packaged and formulated foods and beverages that contained food additives, artificial flavors or colors, or other chemical ingredients. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The categories included processed meat, cold breakfast cereal, various sauces, soft drinks, and fruit drinks, and refined sweetened foods, such as candy, chocolate, jam, jelly, and brownies. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The study included data obtained between 2003 and 2016 from more than 100,000 patients. Overall, 467 participants developed IBD, including 90 with Crohn's disease and 377 with ulcerative colitis. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
These findings are of particular concern, given that a new study found that junk foods account for nearly 70% calories consumed by younger Americans.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In terms of other health risks associated with #IBD, a new study concluded that thrombophilia does not add to the risk for VTE. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The small, case-control study found that, unlike immobilization and surgery, thrombophilia does not appear to be a risk factor for VTE development. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Researchers say the findings do not support exhaustive thrombophilia workup in patients with IBD.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Others have also suggested that these individuals should be screened for specific IBD-related risk factors for VTE development, including hospitalization, immobilization, surgery, and previous and current medications.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
There is quite a bit more IBD research news -- too much to fit in this post. You can tap the link in bio to read the rest. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Endocrine Disruptors and Worldwide Sperm Counts⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Since the early 1990s, infertility is increasing. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Reports now show that 1 in 6 couples have problems conceiving and the use of assisted reproductive technologies is increasing by 5%-10% per year. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Many theories exist to explain these trends, but interestingly, recent data suggest that the most male of all male-specific factors — total sperm count — may be specifically to blame.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
According to a recent meta-analysis, the average total sperm count in men declined by 59.3% between 1973 and 2011. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
While these data certainly have limitations the overall trend nevertheless seems to be clearly downward. And there does not appear to be a leveling off of the downward curve in total sperm count.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Scientists have championed the theory that the widespread exposure to endocrine-disrupting chemicals in everyday plastics may be the prime driver for sperm decline. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
They warn that If indeed the connection between endocrine disruptors and decreased sperm count is borne out, changes in our environmental exposure to these chemicals need to be made.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
What are your thoughts on this topic? Are you seeing other health problems potentially linked to chemical exposure?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This is an excerpt from an article on Medscape. Tap the link in bio for the full report.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Medscape in New York, New York.

node.text:
PFO Closure in Divers Tied to Less Decompression Sickness 🏊⁠
⁠
Patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure in scuba divers might be effective in preventing decompression sickness, a new study suggests.⁠
⁠
An analysis of more than 800 divers showed that those who were screened and then underwent PFO closure were less likely to experience unprovoked decompression sickness than those who took a conservative approach to management.⁠
⁠
"This is the first study to show that PFO closure is effective in DCS prevention in divers with a high-grade PFO," who face an increased risk, Jakub Honěk, MD, PhD, Motol University Hospital, Prague, said in an interview with theheart.org | Medscape Cardiology.⁠
⁠
In contrast, he noted, "a conservative approach to diving that limits nitrogen exposure and allows for more gradual decompression had lower efficacy in this group of divers."⁠
⁠
PFO is associated with an increased risk for decompression sickness in divers due to paradoxical embolization of nitrogen bubbles, the researchers note. "These events can be unpredictable in divers with a PFO."⁠
⁠
The findings were published online in JACC: Cardiovascular Imaging and available on Medscape by tapping the link in bio. ⁠
⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Medscape in New York City, N.Y.. May be an illustration of flower.

node.text:
Aspirin May Show Benefit In Aggressive Breast Cancer ⁠
⁠
A Christie NHS Foundation Trust research team in England has launched a new trial treating triple-negative breast-cancer patients with aspirin.⁠
⁠
They suspect aspirin could fight this aggressive form of breast cancer by making hard-to-treat tumours more responsive to anti-cancer drugs.⁠
⁠
It is aspirin's anti-inflammatory properties rather than its analgesic effect that could make it effective, the researchers said.⁠
⁠
In the trial, researchers said that some patients will be given aspirin as well as immunotherapy drug avelumab before they receive surgery and chemotherapy. ⁠
⁠
If the study is successful it may lead to clinical trials of aspirin + avelumab for incurable secondary triple-negative breast cancer, which is when cancer cells that started in the breast metastasize to other parts of the body.⁠
⁠
The researchers said they hope the trial will show that, when combined with immunotherapy, aspirin can enhance its effects by preventing a weakening of the immune response to cancer drugs. This could lead to a new way to treat breast cancer. ⁠
⁠
However, they also cautioned that it is too soon to recommend aspirin to breast cancer patients. ⁠
⁠
Don't miss any important Medical news. Tap the link in bio to join Medscape. ⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠

node.text:
Medical Monday Case Challenge: ECMO Life Support⁠
⁠
Which of the following patients would be most likely to receive venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) support?⁠
⁠
A) Bridge to lung transplantation⁠
⁠
B) ARDS)⁠
⁠
C) In conjunction with hemodialysis⁠
⁠
D) With cardiogenic shock / cardiac failure ⁠
⁠
Learn more about the fundamental concepts of extracorporeal life support in this CME/CE spotlight for physicians and nurses.⁠
⁠
https://www.medscape.org/viewarticle/955759

node.text:
Soccer Star Med Student Fled the Taliban; About to Be Doctor ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Here's an inspirational story...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
At the end of the year, Nadia Nadim will join the tens of thousands of medical students who will exchange their short white coats for the long ones of practicing physicians. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Unlike other future doctors, this soon-to-be reconstructive surgeon has also been wearing a uniform that's more than white. She has donned brightly colored red, purple, or blue jerseys as a striker for teams in the US National Women's Soccer League and the Danish National football team.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The 33-year-old found her way into medicine after a harrowing childhood. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Following the murder of her father by the Taliban, Nadia, her mother, and her four sisters fled Afghanistan in fear for their lives. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
They sought refuge in Denmark, where Nadia first discovered football [soccer] and a growing call to become a humanitarian activist. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Just one semester away from becoming a doctor, and still sustaining a demanding professional football schedule, Medscape spoke with her about her remarkable story.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
You can read her full interview by tapping the bio link. It's definitely worth a read. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#medstudent #medicalstudent #futuredoctor #medicalschool #inspiration #premed #surgicalteaching #motivationformedicine #shemdmotivation #shemdseries #womendoctor #medstudentlife #futuredr #womeninmedicine #womeninscience #womeninstem

node.text:
Medscape Clinical Trend: Statins⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In encouraging news, statins were again linked to lower COVID-19 mortality. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The findings come from an analysis of data from the AHA's COVID-19 CVD Registry on more than 10,000 patients at 104 hospitals across the US and were published in PLOS One. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Most patients in the study (71%) had either cardiovascular disease, hypertension, or both. Prior to admission, 42% used statins, with 7% taking statins alone and 35% taking statins plus antihypertensives.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Investigators have reiterated that these findings do not suggest that individuals who are not currently taking statins should begin doing so to lower their risk for COVID mortality; however, experts do suggest that those with indications for the drugs should see this as another reason to start taking them if they are not already doing so. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The theory is not necessarily that statins have direct anti-COVID effects but that they are probably helping to stabilize coronary disease. This means that patients are less likely to die from stroke or myocardial infarction, allowing more time and strength for COVID-19 recovery.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
There was much more statin news this week. Tap the link in bio to review all the data. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#cardiology #cardiologie #cardiologist #cardiologista #heart #physician #doctor #medstudent #medicalstudent #futuredoctor #medicine #cardiovasculardisease #Medscape #statins #hypertension #cardiología #physicianassistant

node.text:
Statins May Improve Outcomes in Some Breast Cancer⁠
⁠
Statin use is tied to longer survival in women with triple-negative breast cancer (#TNBC), according to the first study that was adequately powered to investigate this association.⁠
⁠
TNBC, which lacks estrogen and progesterone receptors and excess HER2 protein, makes up roughly 10% to 20% of breast-cancer diagnoses. ⁠
⁠
It's a highly aggressive subtype and has a poor prognosis with limited treatment options.⁠
⁠
Statins have been shown to target pathways related to breast-cancer carcinogenesis, particularly in TNBC, notes the research published in the journal, Cancer. ⁠
⁠
Statins are known to decrease #breastcancer cell division and increase cell death. ⁠
⁠
This study shows that there is an association between #statins and improved outcomes in TNBC, and the study authors noted that it is time to pursue this idea further in a prospective trial.⁠
⁠
Link in bio for full report.
